content: How can I help you today?

I'm not sure, to be honest. My wife pushed me to come here, but I’m skeptical about whether this will even help. Things have been overwhelming lately, and I feel like I don’t even know where to start.

Thank you for sharing that. It sounds like things have been feeling pretty overwhelming for you lately, and that being here is something your wife encouraged. It’s normal to feel uncertain about starting something like this. Would you mind sharing a bit more about what's been on your mind or what feels overwhelming?

I guess it's mostly about my son. He's been acting out a lot lately, and no matter what my wife and I try, nothing seems to help. It's putting so much pressure on us that our marriage feels like it's falling apart. I can't even focus on work or enjoy anything right now. It just feels like there's this endless pile of problems I can't solve.

That sounds like such a heavy weight to carry, with concerns about your son, your marriage, and even your ability to focus and enjoy other parts of life. It must be so difficult to feel like you're trying your best but not seeing the results you'd hoped for. What do you think has been the hardest part of all of this for you?

I think the hardest part is just feeling so helpless. I want to fix things for my son, for my wife, and for my family, but no matter what I do, it feels like I’m failing. It’s hard to even figure out where to start.

It sounds like you really care about your family and want the best for them, but feeling like you’re not able to make things better has left you stuck and overwhelmed. It’s clear that you’re carrying a lot of responsibility for everyone, and it’s understandable that figuring out where to start feels so daunting. When you think about everything going on, is there something—big or small—that feels especially important or urgent to address?

Honestly, it all feels urgent. But I guess if I had to pick one, it’s my son. I don’t know how to help him, and that just makes everything else worse. If we could figure out what’s going on with him, maybe everything else would get a little bit easier.

Focusing on your son feels like a priority because it impacts so much else in your life. That shows how much you care about him and want to support him. It can be so tough when you want to help but aren’t sure what the right steps are. What have you and your wife already tried to support him? And how has that gone so far?

We've tried talking to him, setting clear rules, and even being more lenient at times, hoping he’d open up or start behaving better, but nothing seems to work consistently. Lately, it feels like we don't know how to approach him at all—it’s like walking on eggshells. My wife and I keep getting into arguments about how to handle it, which has just added more stress to the whole situation.

It’s clear that both you and your wife have been putting in so much effort, trying different approaches to support your son and figure out what might help him. It sounds frustrating and exhausting to not see the progress you’re hoping for, especially with tensions growing between you two as a result. What do you think your son might need most from you right now?

I honestly don’t know. Maybe he needs more attention, or maybe I’m doing too much and just making it worse. It’s hard to tell because he doesn’t talk to us about what’s really going on. I just feel so lost when it comes to what he needs.

It sounds really challenging not knowing what your son needs or how to connect with him right now. Feeling lost in that way can be draining, especially when you’re trying so hard to help. What do you think it would take to start understanding him more or opening up those lines of communication?

Maybe if I could figure out why he’s acting out or what’s causing him to shut down, we could go from there. But getting him to open up feels impossible sometimes. I’m not sure he even wants to talk to us. Maybe talking to someone else, like a counselor or someone trained to help kids, could be a step, but I don't know if he'd be open to it. Honestly, I’m not sure where to even start.

It sounds like you’re really thoughtful about wanting to understand and help your son, while also recognizing how tough it’s been to bridge that gap. Thinking about a professional or counselor could be a way to give him the space to open up in a different environment, especially if he’s finding it hard to do so at home. It’s clear you’re exploring different options and really putting his needs first. What do you think would help you feel more confident about taking that next step, whatever it may be?

I think knowing where to start would help. If I knew who to reach out to or what kind of counselor would actually work for him, maybe I’d feel more confident. But I also worry about whether it’ll really make a difference, or if he’ll even be willing to go. It’s hard to feel like this will work when nothing else has so far.

It makes sense that, after trying so many things already, it’s hard to believe something new will make a difference. Your concerns about finding the right support and whether your son will be open to it are really understandable. You’re doing the best you can in a tough situation, and recognizing that you may need help is such a thoughtful step forward. Would it help to start by gathering some information together—with no pressure to act right away—and see if anything stands out as a good option for your family?

I think that could help. If I had some resources or options to look into, it might feel less overwhelming. I can at least take that first step and see what’s out there. Maybe my wife and I can go through it together and find something that feels right for him. This whole situation just feels so out of control, and I want to do what I can to fix it.

That sounds like a really caring and thoughtful first step—exploring options together with your wife to see what feels like the best fit for your son. It shows how committed you both are to finding a way to support him and start addressing things as a family. Taking that step, even if it’s small, can help you regain some sense of control in what’s been an overwhelming situation. How are you feeling about moving forward with that plan? And is there anything else that’s been on your mind that you’d like to explore further today?

You know, I think starting with this plan feels like a step in the right direction. Focusing on finding resources and doing it with my wife feels doable right now, even though everything still feels difficult. I think this is a good place to stop for today—thank you for listening and helping me think this through.
